name: Tracing Materials: From Resource to Waste to Art
description:
What does ‘material’ or ‘medium’ mean to an artist? Do materials themselves provide rich narratives and social histories? Visual artist Arunkumar H G certainly thinks so! In this workshop he delves into the origins and historical contexts of materials, while they transform from resources to waste.

For this workshop, you are encouraged to bring your own accumulation of waste, to examine how we perceive and interpret waste. You will then work with Arunkumar H G to transform these materials into art objects, highlighting the qualities and significance of the seemingly mundane.

name: Building Resilient Climate Futures: Exploring AI in Climate Action
description:
Can AI and other technological tools affect the future of climate action in Asia? And how can you assess these nuanced climate futures?

Join researchers Dona Mathew and Sasha John in a workshop that delves into the intersection of AI and climate action, while highlighting the Digital Futures Lab's research. Discover how to spot trends and signals that hint at future climate scenarios through hands-on activities. Imagine and design the climate futures you want to see, guided by foresight methodologies and creative thinking exercises.

name: Energy Transitions: Work, Labour, and Tradeoffs
description:
Join political scientist Rohit Chandra, social scientist Radhika Krishnan and physicist Shoibal Chakravarty to dive into the complexities of energy transition in India. This masterclass will be spread over two sessions, exploring the transition from fossil fuels to alternative sources.

Session 1

How do we understand energy transition dynamics through the lens of labour and work? What are the working conditions in coal-dependent regions of India? Where do these workers' lives intersect with local institutions? Join Radhika Krishnan and Rohit Chandra to think about some of the labour realities of the energy transition. Rooted in social science methods, this masterclass session will prompt you to consider the perspective of India's millions of energy-sector workers when thinking about energy transitions.


Session 2

How do we decide what energy technologies to use for the next half-century? What kinds of social, economic, and environmental factors need consideration when making such decisions? In this session, Shoibal Chakravarty and political scientist Rohit Chandra will unpack some of the pressing trade-offs in India's energy transition. This masterclass will explore trade-offs as varied as energy poverty, employment, public health and regional equity. By evaluating some of these trade-offs using economic and techno-economic methods, you can learn how to assess these trade-offs at different levels of magnification (individual, firm, state, country).

name: Coal in India: Decarbonisation After Development
description:
Coal generates over 65% of India's power today, but it is also one of India's largest sources of greenhouse gas emissions. Why is India ambivalent in its approach to the coal industry? What does it have to do with the history of developmentalism in this country?

By examining the post-Independence history of the Indian coal industry, Rohit Chandra will discuss some of the complicated social, economic, and regional consequences of India's necessary trajectory of decarbonization. The lecture will also discuss some of the historical figures who have significantly influenced the industry's trajectory since Independence.
